Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Expanding Developers' Usage of Software Tools by Enabling Social Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Creating and maintaining software is an increasing challenge for software developers. Software development tools can help meet this challenge, but most developers use only a small subset of the available tools because they are unaware of the existence of relevant tools. To learn about relevant tools, prior work suggests that most effective approach is social learning, where a developer learns about a tool from a peer, yet research also suggests that social tool learning is rare. The aim of this research is to increase the frequency and effectiveness of social tool learning, and in turn, fundamentally advance our understanding of how technology can mediate tool learning in software development and beyond. In reaching this aim, we will help improve the software on which people increasingly rely.

The researchers will create a testbed system that will record a continuous screencast of the developer's work, indexed with time-stamped data on tool usage. By comparing the developer's tool usage data with her peers', the system selects a list of candidate tools that the developer does not use, but that her peers do use. The system then encourages peers to teach and learn from one another by sharing tool-usage clips chosen from each others' screencasts. The approach aims to enable distributed and asynchronous developers to share tool knowledge efficiently, effectively, and frequently. The testbed will allow the researchers to experiment with various types of tool learning to determine how, why, and when different types of tool learning are effective or ineffective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tools can help software developers substantially increase the velocity of their engineering process and the quality of the software they create. Yet the sheer number of tools available makes it difficult for developers to find and apply useful tools to their work. This project?s primary goal was to understand and enhance how software developers learn about new tools from their peers. To that end, the project performed several studies of software developers to learn what makes such a discovery process efficient and effective. Several techniques were then invented to facilitate the process of tool discovery so that software developers can more effectively find the tools they need. The project has also investigated the effects of gender bias in open source, providing novel and foundational results into the challenges faced by traditionally excluded groups from computer science.

 

Research results have appeared in top-tier software engineering publications, including the International Conference on Software Engineering. Technology discoveries have been made freely available as open source software on GitHub. Three graduate students have been supported by this project, who have been trained in empirical study design, data gathering, data analysis, and research methods. Furthermore, three undergraduate students have been involved in various aspects of this project.
